none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Robert F. Smith, July 7, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Robert F. Smith, July 7, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 22 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Social life and customs--United States--19th century

en: A personal letter from Robert F. Smith in Orange, New Jersey to Professor Louis L. McInnis in Forest, Mississippi, describing Smith's travels and leisure activities in the northeastern United States. Smith details his visits to major attractions including Niagara Falls, Chautauqua Lake, Brooklyn's Prospect Park, and various New York locations, as well as his social encounters and plans for further tourism. The letter provides insight into recreational travel practices and social customs during the summer of 1886.

body.value:

July 7. 86.

Prof. L. L. McInnis,
Forest
Miss.

Have not been around

**Thought Process: Transcribing a Handwritten Letter** Okay, so I've got this handwritten letter and the task is to transcribe it. First, I need to analyze the image to identify key elements. There's a floral design at the top left, which I'll note but won't be transcribing. Then there's the location and date, "Orange New Jersey / July 7. 86." - clearly 1886. The recipient is "Prof. L. L. McInnis, / Forest / Miss.", and the salutation is "Dear Prof.:". Next, I'll move on to a detailed transcription strategy. I'll note down the date, "July 7. 86.", and confirm the "86" is clear. I see the name is "Prof. L. L. McInnis" and I'll confirm the middle initial as L, and the last name starting with Mc, then I, n, n, i, s. The location is "Forest / Miss." (Mississippi). Then, I'll transcribe each line of the body text. Now, let's think about formatting. I'll use `

"Forest" is underlined, as is "Miss.", both with no trailing punctuation. "Dear Prof.:" has a colon at the end, and the body begins indented. I need to note the hyphens in "spend-" and "writ-". There's the tricky word "Having" versus "having." In the script, the letter "H" appears to be capitalized, but it looks like grammatically it is lowercase. Looking closely at the letter, however, the looped ascender of the 'h' matches the looped ascender of the "H" in "Have", thus I'll transcribe "Having." The letter ends abruptly with "through a large". And "Produce Exch." is clearly an abbreviation. I'll double-check my work against the guidelines: the transcription should be top-to-bottom, I'll preserve spelling and punctuation, use `[?]` when unsure, and keep to allowed HTML tags. I've noted "Forest" has a flourish at the end. "Miss." ends with a period. The "Dear Prof.:" has a colon. And there are hyphens in "spend-" and "writ-". I am confident that the "H" in "Having" is capitalized in the original script. Finally I'll check "Exch" which has a period. steam ship, across the
suspension bridge to Brook-
lyn and there visited
Prospect Park. This is about
all I have seen of N.Y.
Will begin systematically
to "paint" the town in a
few days. Called at Van
Winkle's office one day;
but he was out. At
Cleveland, and Dunkirk
N.Y. we stopped two weeks
and it was a perpetual
picnic all the time.

At the latter place, we were
on the lake a great deal—
fishing, rowing and picnic
ing. Met lots of lively girls
at both places. I have met
several here; but have been

**A Deep Dive into Textual Transcription: My Thought Process** Alright, let's break this down. The task is clear: I need to transform this handwritten document into a clean, digital format. First, I'm assessing the source. It's a page from a letter, judging by the cursive handwriting, which has that classic late 19th or early 20th-century feel. The ink is faded, a sepia-toned brown – not the crispest image, but the lines are still discernible on the lined paper. Now, it's transcription time. I'm going line by line, ensuring accuracy. I'm noting potential ambiguities, like that initial word "steam ship," and making sure I'm capturing everything exactly as it's written. I'm paying close attention to punctuation: are those periods or commas? And is that an em-dash at the end of line 16? I am cross-referencing to previous lines, or to common phrases. I am checking the spacing to ensure correct line breaks as well. I keep reviewing my transcription, checking for idioms like "paint the town" and common phrases. I'm verifying the capitalization and punctuation, especially with abbreviations like "N.Y.". I'm also ensuring the meaning is correct with context in mind (is "rowing" the right word, or did they mean "waving"? In this case, "rowing" on the lake makes sense, so I will select it). I will focus on proper nouns, so I get the spelling right. "Cleveland" has that distinctive curly C, and it makes sense contextually, so I verify that. I'm even checking for any implied paragraphs based on indentation. Line 15, "At the latter place...", is clearly indented, and a new paragraph makes the most sense there. I then check again to make sure all is correct. I am now doing the final layout, using HTML `
` tags for line breaks and `

` tags for paragraph structure, preserving any subtle indentation that might be present. In this case, I will split the text into two paragraphs: One running from the start, and the second one starts with the indented line 15 ("At..."). And there it is: a faithful digital reproduction of the handwritten text, ready for use!

Albany by rail and
then took the day boat
to New York. I enjoyed
the scenery along the Hud-
son, especially the High-
lands and Palisades be-
low West Pt. I want to
get to W. Pt. and up the
Catskills before I go back.
Very likely I'll take them
in on my return trip.
Mrs. W. and E. are both well;
but complain of being
tired still. They send love
to Mrs. McL. and Miss McL.
E. is very anxious for you
to bring them with you
when you come East.
Kindest regards to all.

[Signature]
Your friend Robt P. Smith.
